questions.text: What is the most common skin tumour associated with and the most commonly mutated gene in Muir-Torre syndrome?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Muir-Torre syndrome (MTS) is a variant of Lynch syndrome characterised by the presence of sebaceous gland neoplasms along with visceral malignancies, especially colorectal and genitourinary cancers.

  • Most common skin tumour: Sebaceous adenoma
  • Most common gene mutated: MSH2 (a DNA mismatch repair gene)
  • These tumours may be the first manifestation of underlying Lynch syndrome.
  • Sebaceous tumours include sebaceous adenomas, epitheliomas, and carcinomas; among these, adenomas are most frequently reported.
  • MSH2 mutation results in microsatellite instability and defective DNA repair, contributing to tumorigenesis.

Explanation of Other Options:

Basal cell carcinoma, MSH2 (Option A): Basal cell carcinoma is not classically associated with Muir-Torre syndrome. MSH2 is correct, but the tumour type is incorrect.

Sebaceous adenoma, MSH6 (Option B): Sebaceous adenoma is correct, but the MSH6 mutation is less common than the MSH2 mutation in MTS.

Sebaceous carcinoma, MSH6 (Option D): Sebaceous carcinoma is a known tumour in MTS, but less frequent than adenoma; MSH6 is not the most common mutation.

questions.text: False statement regarding melanocytic nevus:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Neurotization is a typical feature of melanocytic nevi and is not seen in melanomas.

  • Melanocytic nevi are common benign neoplasms caused in most cases by acquired activating mutations in components of the RAS-RAF-MAPK signalling pathway.
  • The earliest lesion in the nevus evolution is a junctional nevus, composed of nests of nevus cells at the dermoepidermal junction.
  • Hormonal changes, such as during pregnancy, may cause nevi to become more prominent.
  • As nevi mature, deeper nevus cells often acquire fusiform shapes and grow in fascicles, resembling neural tissue - this is called neurotization, and it is absent in melanoma.

(Other options are ruled out)

Key Takeaways:

choices.text: Also called familial atypical multiple mole and melanoma syndrome
Increases the risk of pancreatic cancer

questions.text: True statements about dysplastic nevus syndrome are:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Dysplastic nevus syndrome is a well-defined inherited disorder characterised by multiple dysplastic nevi and a significantly increased risk of developing melanoma, especially by the age of 60.

  • Other names: Also referred to as familial atypical multiple mole and melanoma syndrome (FAMMM).
  • Inheritance pattern: It follows an autosomal dominant mode of inheritance.
  • Associated malignancies: Besides melanoma, pancreatic cancer risk is also increased in some families with this syndrome.

(Other options ruled out)

choices.text: Linear fibrosis occurs around epidermal rete ridges involved by the nevus
Lymphocytic infiltrate may be seen in the epidermis
Presence of cytological atypia in the form of irregular nuclear contours and hyperchromasia

questions.text: Regarding histology of dysplastic nevi, all are correct except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Lymphocytic infiltrates are seen in the superficial dermis, not the epidermis. Dysplastic nevi show distinct histological changes, which help differentiate them from ordinary nevi and signal their potential for malignant transformation.

Histopathological Features of Dysplastic Nevi:

(Other options are ruled out)

  • Dysplastic nevi are often larger than acquired nevi and show both architectural and cytological atypia.
  • Cytological atypia includes nuclear enlargement, hyperchromasia, and angular contours.
  • Dermal changes include lymphocytic infiltrates and linear fibrosis surrounding involved rete ridges.
  • Melanin incontinence is commonly observed, with melanin being engulfed by dermal macrophages.
  • Rete ridges involved by the nevus exhibit lentiginous melanocytic hyperplasia.
  • These lesions are clinically significant due to their potential to transform into melanoma, especially in the setting of dysplastic nevus syndrome.

questions.text: Which of the following mutations is not commonly associated with melanoma?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

KRAS is not a common mutation in melanoma; rather, it is typically implicated in cancers such as colorectal, pancreatic, and lung adenocarcinoma. In contrast, melanoma frequently harbours mutations in TERT, CDKN2A, and BRAF.

  • BRAF mutations are present in 40–50% of melanomas and activate the MAPK pathway (RAS-RAF-MEK-ERK).
  • CDKN2A mutations affect both p16INK4a and p14ARF, leading to loss of control over both Rb and p53 tumour suppressor pathways.
  • TERT promoter mutations are among the most commonly mutated genes in melanoma, seen in ~70% of cases.
  • KRAS, although related to the RAS pathway, is not typically mutated in melanomas per current evidence.

Explanation of Other Options:

TERT (Option A): Frequently mutated in melanoma, enhances telomerase expression.

CDKN2A (Option B): Involved in familial melanoma syndromes, regulates p16 and p14.

BRAF (Option D): A key oncogene in melanoma, downstream of RAS in the MAPK pathway.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male has just been diagnosed with melanoma. Which type of melanoma has the worst prognosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Nodular melanoma has the worst prognosis because it enters the vertical growth phase early, which is associated with early invasion and metastatic potential.

  • Melanoma progresses in two phases: radial and vertical growth phase.
  • The radial phase involves lateral spread within the epidermis and superficial dermis, often for years, and is not associated with metastatic potential.
  • The vertical growth phase is marked by tumour growth downward into the deeper dermis and is associated with metastatic potential.
  • Nodular melanoma shows early vertical growth, bypassing or having minimal radial growth phase, leading to early appearance of nodules and a high risk of metastasis.
  • This is in contrast to superficial spreading melanoma, acral lentiginous melanoma, and lentigo maligna melanoma, which typically exhibit prolonged radial growth and hence better prognosis if caught early.

Explanation of Other Options:

Acral-lentiginous melanoma (Option A): Occurs on palms, soles, under nails; common in dark-skinned people; prognosis worse than superficial spreading but not as bad as nodular.

Lentigo maligna melanoma (Option C): Typically has a long radial growth phase and slower progression; seen in the elderly on sun-damaged skin.

Superficial spreading melanoma (Option D): Most common type; long radial phase gives time for early detection, hence relatively better prognosis.

Key Takeaways:

choices.text: Deepest margin of tumour cells to the upper extent of the tumour
Epidermal granular layer to the deepest intraepidermal tumour cells
Stratum corneum to the deepest intradermal tumour cells
Stratum basale to deepest intradermal tumour cells

questions.text: Tumour depth of invasion is denoted by Breslow thickness, and it is calculated from:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Breslow thickness is the most important histopathological factor used to predict prognosis in melanoma, and it directly correlates with survival outcomes. It is defined as the vertical distance in millimetres from the top of the epidermal granular layer (if the skin is intact) to the deepest point of invasion by melanoma cells.

  • If the overlying epidermis is ulcerated, the measurement begins from the base of the ulcer to the deepest point of tumour cell penetration.
  • The deeper the tumour extends into the dermis or subcutaneous tissue, the worse the prognosis.
  • Along with ulceration, mitotic figures, and the presence of tumour-infiltrating lymphocytes, Breslow thickness helps guide clinical decision-making and staging.

Explanation of Other Options:

Deepest margin of tumour cells to upper extent of tumour (Option A): Incorrect; this reverses the measurement direction and ignores the anatomical skin landmarks.

Stratum corneum to deepest intradermal tumour cells (Option C): Incorrect; the stratum corneum is an unreliable landmark and is not used in standard measurement due to its variable thickness.

Stratum basale to deepest intradermal tumour cells (Option D): Incorrect; Breslow depth starts from the granular layer, not the basal layer.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a marker used in the diagnosis of melanoma?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

SOX9 is not a recognised immunohistochemical marker for melanoma; it is primarily involved in cartilage development. In contrast, S-100, HMB-45, and SOX10 are established diagnostic markers used in the identification of melanoma.

Immunohistochemical Markers of Melanoma:

questions.text: Dermatosis papulosa nigra refers to:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Dermatosis papulosa nigra refers to the presence of multiple small seborrheic keratoses on the face, particularly common in African-American adults. It is a benign epithelial tumour variant with a characteristic clinical appearance.

  • Seborrheic keratosis is a common epidermal tumour derived from keratinising epithelium.
  • Multiple facial lesions in this category, especially in individuals with darker skin tones, are referred to as dermatosis papulosa nigra.
  • These lesions are typically small, dark brown to black, round, and occur most frequently in middle-aged or older individuals.
  • They are benign and have no malignant potential.

Explanation of Other Options:

Acanthosis nigricans (Option A): Hyperpigmented, velvety plaques commonly seen in intertriginous areas; associated with insulin resistance or malignancy.

Plaque psoriasis (Option C): Chronic inflammatory disease with scaly, erythematous plaques typically on extensor surfaces.

Pilomatricoma (Option D): Benign skin tumour of hair matrix origin; not related to seborrheic keratosis or DPN.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presented to the OPD with multiple flat, round, brownish, sub-centimetric lesions over the trunk for 1 month. Which of the following statements is true regarding this condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Exuberant hyperkeratosis occurs at the surface, small keratin-filled cysts (horn cysts) and invaginations of keratin into the main mass (invagination cysts) are characteristic features. Seborrheic keratosis may suddenly appear in large numbers as part of paraneoplastic syndrome (Leser-Trelat sign).

  • These lesions represent benign proliferation of epidermal keratinocytes.
  • Genetic aspect:
    • Activating mutations in the fibroblast growth factor receptor 3 (FGFR3) gene are found in many sporadic cases.
  • Histopathology:
    • Characterised by exuberant surface hyperkeratosis.
    • Horn cysts (intraepidermal keratin-filled cysts) and invagination cysts (keratin invaginating into the lesion) are classically seen.
  • Paraneoplastic association:
    • Sudden appearance of multiple lesions, particularly in older adults, may be a paraneoplastic sign called the Leser-Trélat sign.
    • Commonly associated with underlying gastric adenocarcinoma, but also reported with other visceral malignancies.
  • These features are diagnostic when considered together and may require additional systemic evaluation if rapidly progressive.

(Other options ruled out)

questions.text: A 30-year-old male underwent biopsy for papules on his forehead for 2 weeks, and the histology shows compact nests of basaloid cells surrounded by a thick basement membrane. diagnosis
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Cylindroma is a benign adnexal (appendageal) tumour that arises from apocrine or eccrine glands.

  • Site: Typically involves the forehead and scalp, sometimes forming large coalescent masses referred to as "turban tumours".
  • Histology:
    • Composed of islands of basaloid cells.
    • These islands fit together like jigsaw puzzle pieces.
    • Located within a fibrous stroma.
    • Cells resemble the basal cell layer of the epidermis or adnexal epithelium.

This characteristic jigsaw puzzle appearance is pathognomonic for cylindroma, helping to differentiate it from other basaloid tumours.

Explanation of Other Options:

Pilomatricoma (Option B): Shows basaloid cells with abrupt keratinisation forming "ghost cells", not jigsaw nests.

Syringoma (Option C): Composed of small ducts within a fibrotic stroma; commonly occurs on the lower eyelids.

Trichoepithelioma (Option D): Composed of basaloid cell islands resembling primitive hair follicles with papillary mesenchymal bodies, but lacks the jigsaw puzzle pattern.

questions.text: Ghost cells are seen in:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Ghost cells are hallmark features of Pilomatricoma.

  • Definition: Ghost cells are anucleated epithelial cells with eosinophilic cytoplasm that retain the outline of the original cell.
  • Appearance: Enlarged, pink-staining keratinised cells lacking nuclei, commonly seen in areas of abrupt keratinisation.
  • Seen in:
    • Pilomatricoma
    • Craniopharyngioma
    • Calcifying odontogenic cyst
    • Odontoma, Ameloblastic fibroma
  • These cells are indicative of abnormal keratinisation and are not seen in the other appendage tumours listed.

Explanation of Other Options:

Trichoepithelioma (Option A): Composed of basaloid cells resembling primitive hair follicles; shows peripheral palisading but no ghost cells.

Cylindroma (Option B): Features islands of basaloid cells arranged like a jigsaw puzzle within a fibrous stroma; ghost cells are absent.

Sebaceous adenoma (Option C): Shows lobular proliferation of sebocytes with bubbly cytoplasm due to lipid; does not contain ghost cells.

questions.text: Basal cell layer dysplasia associated with hyper- and parakeratosis is seen in:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Actinic keratosis shows histological features that may include both hyperkeratosis (thickened stratum corneum) and parakeratosis (retention of nuclei in the stratum corneum). Dysplasia is often seen in the basal layer, which may herald the progression to squamous cell carcinoma.

Explanation of Other Options:

Cylindroma (Option A): Shows jigsaw-like nests of basaloid cells surrounded by thick basement membrane; no parakeratosis or basal dysplasia.

Trichoepithelioma (Option B): Basaloid cell proliferation with follicular differentiation; not associated with hyperkeratosis or parakeratosis.

Psoriasis (Option D): Shows parakeratosis but lacks basal cell layer dysplasia, which is a hallmark of actinic keratosis.

questions.text: Xeroderma pigmentosum is associated with
questions.solution:
Explanation:

All listed features are associated with xeroderma pigmentosum (XP), a genetic disorder caused by defective nucleotide excision repair, predisposing to various skin malignancies.

  • XP is a rare inherited disorder that impairs the ability to repair UV-induced DNA damage via the nucleotide excision repair (NER) pathway.
  • Patients exhibit extreme sensitivity to sunlight and have a markedly increased risk of cutaneous squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) and basal cell carcinoma (BCC), often at a young age.
  • The characteristic pathogenesis includes mutations in genes such as XPA through XPG, which are essential for the NER pathway.

(Other options ruled out)

questions.text: Multiple basal cell carcinomas, medulloblastomas, ovarian fibromas, and odontogenic keratocysts are seen in:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Gorlin syndrome (Nevoid Basal Cell Carcinoma Syndrome – NBCCS) is an autosomal dominant disorder caused by a mutation in the PTCH1 gene on chromosome 9q22, leading to unregulated Hedgehog pathway activation. It is characterised by:

  • A mutation in PTCH1 leads to activation of SMO (Smoothened) and downstream GLI1, causing uncontrolled cell proliferation and tumorigenesis.
  • Tumours often begin before age 20 and may include medulloblastoma and ovarian fibroma.
  • Histologically, BCCs in Gorlin syndrome arise from follicular epithelium and are indolent in nature.

Explanation of Other Options:

Muir-Torre syndrome (Option B): Subtype of Lynch syndrome; characterised by sebaceous neoplasms and visceral malignancies (e.g., colorectal carcinoma); caused by DNA mismatch repair gene mutations like MSH2 and MLH1.

Cowden syndrome (Option C): Caused by PTEN mutation; characterised by hamartomas, breast/endometrial/thyroid carcinomas, and trichilemmomas, not BCCs or odontogenic cysts.

Tuberous sclerosis (Option D): Caused by TSC1/TSC2 mutation; associated with cortical tubers, subependymal giant cell astrocytoma, renal angiomyolipoma, not odontogenic cysts or BCCs.

questions.text: A true palisading pattern can be seen in
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Basal cell carcinoma shows a true palisading pattern, where the tumour cells at the periphery are arranged radially with their long axes in parallel alignment to form a palisading pattern. This is a histopathological hallmark of basal cell carcinoma.

Explanation of Other Options:

Pilomatrixoma (Option A): Shows basophilic cells with ghost cells, but does not exhibit palisading.

Squamous cell carcinoma (Option B): Characterised by keratin pearls and intercellular bridges, no palisading pattern.

Cylindroma (Option D): Shows a jigsaw puzzle or mosaic pattern, not palisading.

questions.text: False statement regarding basal cell carcinoma
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Metastasis is very rare in basal cell carcinoma (BCC), even in advanced stages. However, BCC can show an extensive local invasion, sometimes involving bone or sinuses over long durations.

(Other options ruled out)

questions.text: Most common malignancy of the eyelid:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Basal cell carcinoma (BCC) is the most common malignancy of the eyelid and is locally invasive. It shows a distinct predilection for the lower eyelid and medial canthus.

Explanation of Other Options:

Sebaceous carcinoma (Option A): Less common than BCC. It can mimic inflammatory conditions and has metastatic potential. May be associated with Muir-Torre syndrome.

SCC (Option C): Though it occurs on the skin, it is not the most common eyelid malignancy. Less frequent than BCC.

Melanoma (Option D): Extremely rare in the eyelid. Eyelid melanomas are seldom encountered compared to other skin sites.

choices.text: Composed of fibroblasts arranged in a storiform pattern
May extend to subcutis and rarely metastasise
Imatinib can be used for unresectable tumours

questions.text: True statements regarding Dermatofibrosarcoma protuberans include:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Dermatofibrosarcoma protuberans (DFSP) is a well-differentiated fibrosarcoma with local aggressiveness, slow growth, and rare metastasis.

  • It is composed of closely packed fibroblasts arranged in a storiform (cartwheel-like) pattern.
  • These tumours extend into the subcutis, showing characteristic "honeycomb" infiltration, and can recur locally if not completely excised.
  • The molecular hallmark is a translocation involving COL1A1 and PDGFB, leading to PDGF overexpression.
  • In unresectable cases or those with metastasis, imatinib (a tyrosine kinase inhibitor) targeting PDGF receptor may be used.

questions.text: A 26-year-old male presented to the OPD with multiple flat-topped papules over the trunk. A biopsy was taken, and the histology is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The histological image shows classic features of psoriasis:

  • Regular elongation of the rete ridges (acanthosis)
  • Parakeratosis (nuclei in stratum corneum)
  • Suprapapillary thinning
  • Munro microabscesses (neutrophils in stratum corneum)

These findings are diagnostic of psoriasis.

Explanation of Other Options:

Lichen planus (Option A): Shows saw-toothing of rete ridges, band-like lymphocytic infiltrate at the dermoepidermal junction, hypergranulosis, and Civatte bodies.

Molluscum contagiosum (Option C): Umbilicated lesions with large eosinophilic cytoplasmic inclusions (molluscum bodies) in the epidermis.

Dermatitis herpetiformis (Option D): Shows neutrophilic microabscesses in dermal papillae with subepidermal blistering, not seen here.

questions.text: Cutaneous manifestations of metabolic syndrome include which of the following?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

All three options listed are associated with metabolic syndrome as cutaneous manifestations.

  • Acanthosis nigricans is strongly associated with insulin resistance and obesity.
  • Acrochordons (skin tags) are common in individuals with metabolic syndrome and insulin resistance.
  • Psoriasis is also associated with metabolic syndrome components such as obesity, diabetes, and dyslipidemia.

(Other options ruled out)

questions.text: Civatte bodies are seen in:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Civatte bodies are anucleate necrotic basal cells that are a histological hallmark of lichen planus.

  • They result from basal cell degeneration and are incorporated into the papillary dermis due to chronic interface dermatitis.

Explanation of Other Options:

Psoriasis (Option A): Shows regular elongation of rete ridges, parakeratosis, and Munro microabscesses, not Civatte bodies.

Seborrheic dermatitis (Option C): Characterised by spongiosis, parakeratosis, and superficial perivascular inflammation, no Civatte bodies.

Pemphigus vulgaris (Option D): Shows suprabasal blister formation with acantholysis of keratinocytes, Civatte bodies not seen.

questions.text: A Prototypic example of interface dermatitis is:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Lichen planus is the prototypic example of interface dermatitis, characterised histologically by a dense, continuous, band-like infiltrate of lymphocytes along the dermoepidermal junction.

  • This immune response targets basal epidermal cells and causes damage, leading to basal cell degeneration, hypergranulosis, and Civatte body formation.

Explanation of Other Options:

Psoriasis (Option B): Shows epidermal hyperplasia, parakeratosis, neutrophils in stratum corneum (Munro microabscesses); not an interface dermatitis.

Urticaria (Option C): A transient dermal oedema with sparse perivascular infiltrate; lacks dermoepidermal junction involvement.

Seborrheic dermatitis (Option D): Spongiosis and superficial inflammation; not an interface pattern.

questions.text: The immunofluorescence image below is diagnostic of which disease, and what is the primary target antigen?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The image shows a fish-net pattern of IgG deposition between keratinocytes on direct immunofluorescence, typical of pemphigus vulgaris.

  • Pemphigus vulgaris is due to autoantibodies against desmoglein-3 (Dsg3).
  • Dsg3 is present in the deep epidermis and mucosal epithelium, explaining mucosal involvement.
  • Pemphigus foliaceus involves Dsg1 and is more superficial.
  • Bullous pemphigoid shows linear basement membrane zone staining due to BPAG2 antibodies.

(Other options ruled out)

questions.text: Split skin immunofluorescence is used in the diagnosis of which condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Split skin immunofluorescence is a modified indirect immunofluorescence technique used to differentiate between various bullous (blistering) disorders, such as pemphigus vulgaris and bullous pemphigoid, based on the location of IgG deposition.

  • In pemphigus vulgaris, antibodies target desmosomal proteins between keratinocytes → intercellular (fish-net) fluorescence pattern.
  • In bullous pemphigoid, antibodies target hemidesmosomal proteins at the dermoepidermal junction → linear fluorescence along the basement membrane.
  • The split-skin technique helps identify whether the antibodies bind to the epidermal or dermal side of artificially split skin.

Explanation of Other Options:

Psoriasis (Option A): Not a blistering disease; no role for split skin immunofluorescence.

Parakeratosis (Option C): Seen in psoriasis; unrelated to autoimmune blistering; not evaluated by immunofluorescence.

Lupus vulgaris (Option D): Cutaneous TB; diagnosed via histopathology, not split-skin immunofluorescence.

questions.text: Subcorneal bullae are seen in
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Pemphigus foliaceus is a blistering disorder where the split occurs just beneath the stratum corneum, resulting in subcorneal bullae. This location of blistering helps differentiate it from other vesiculobullous disorders.

  • Subcorneal bullae are seen in:
    • Pemphigus foliaceus
    • Impetigo
    • Staphylococcal Scalded Skin Syndrome (SSSS)
  • Suprabasal bullae are seen in:
    • Pemphigus vulgaris (split just above the basal layer; "row of tombstones" appearance) (Option B ruled out)
  • Subepidermal bullae are seen in:
    • Bullous pemphigoid (Option A ruled out)
    • Dermatitis herpetiformis (Option D ruled out)
    • Linear IgA bullous dermatosis

Key Takeaways:

questions.text: A 60-year-old male presented with tense bullae filled with clear fluid involving erythematous skin, diagnosis
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The histopathological image demonstrates a subepidermal blister with an intact epidermis lifted off from the underlying dermis, along with a dense inflammatory infiltrate consisting of eosinophils and occasional neutrophils, features characteristic of bullous pemphigoid.

  • Bullous pemphigoid is an autoimmune blistering disease caused by antibodies targeting hemidesmosomal proteins (BPAG1 and BPAG2), resulting in subepidermal separation.
  • Clinically, lesions are tense bullae filled with clear fluid on erythematous or normal skin, and they typically do not rupture easily.
  • Histopathology shows subepidermal blister formation with eosinophilic infiltration in the upper dermis.

Explanation of Other Options:

Pemphigus vulgaris (Option A): Shows suprabasal blister with tombstone appearance; not subepidermal.

Epidermolysis bullosa (Option C): Genetic disorder; subepidermal blisters without significant inflammation.

Dermatitis herpetiformis (Option D): Subepidermal blister with neutrophilic microabscesses at dermal papillae; associated with gluten sensitivity.

questions.text: Cerebriform or scrotal tongue is a feature of
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Cerebriform or scrotal tongue is an early diagnostic clue in pemphigus vegetans and represents vegetative plaques involving the mucosa.

  • Pemphigus vegetans is a rare variant of pemphigus vulgaris characterised by large, moist, vegetating plaques, often seen in intertriginous areas.
  • Oral mucosal involvement is common, and cerebriform or scrotal tongue is considered a pathognomonic finding.
  • Histologically, pemphigus vegetans shows suprabasal blister formation with epidermal hyperplasia and eosinophilic infiltrate.

Explanation of Other Options:

Pemphigus vulgaris (Option A): Shows suprabasal acantholysis and is the most common type. Oral erosions are prominent, but cerebriform tongue is not a defining feature.

Pemphigus foliaceous (Option C): Involves subcorneal acantholysis. No mucosal involvement; cerebriform tongue not seen.

Pemphigus erythematosus (Option D): A localised form of pemphigus foliaceous with lupus overlap. It does not present with vegetative plaques or cerebriform tongue.

questions.text: All are bullous disorders except
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Pemphigus vegetans is a rare variant of pemphigus that does not typically present with bullae. Instead, it manifests as large, moist, wart-like, vegetating plaques with pustules, most commonly in flexural areas such as the groin and axilla.

  • It shows suprabasal acantholysis histologically, similar to pemphigus vulgaris, but clinically presents with verrucous vegetations, not typical bullae.
  • In contrast, the other three options-pemphigus vulgaris, pemphigus foliaceous, and pemphigus erythematosus - are classic bullous disorders with intraepidermal acantholytic blistering.

Explanation of Other Options:

Pemphigus vulgaris (Option A): Classic bullous disorder with suprabasal acantholysis and mucocutaneous erosions.

Pemphigus foliaceous (Option C): Bullae are superficial (subcorneal); no mucosal involvement.

Pemphigus erythematosus (Option D): Localised variant with features of both pemphigus foliaceous and lupus; subcorneal bullae seen.

questions.text: The immunofluorescence image shown below is from a patient with grouped vesicular lesions over extensor surfaces. What is the most likely finding?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Granular IgA deposition at the tips of dermal papillae is a characteristic feature of dermatitis herpetiformis and is visualised on direct immunofluorescence (DIF) as seen in the image.

  • Dermatitis herpetiformis is a chronic autoimmune blistering disorder associated with gluten sensitivity.
  • Histologically, it shows subepidermal blister with neutrophilic microabscesses at dermal papillae.
  • DIF shows discontinuous, granular deposits of IgA localised to the tips of dermal papillae.

Explanation of Other Options:

Linear deposits of IgA (Option A): Seen in Linear IgA Bullous Dermatosis, not DH.

Linear deposits of IgG (Option C): Characteristic of Bullous Pemphigoid, along the basement membrane.

Granular deposits of IgG (Option D): Not a known pattern in bullous diseases.

choices.text: Regular downward elongation of rete ridges

questions.text: All of the following are histology features of psoriasis except
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Hypergranulosis is not a feature of psoriasis. Instead, psoriasis typically shows thinning or complete absence of the granular layer (hypogranulosis).

Based on the histologic findings in psoriasis:

  • There is marked acanthosis (epidermal thickening).
  • Rete ridges show regular downward elongation, often described as resembling test tubes in a rack.
  • The stratum granulosum is thinned or absent (not hypergranulosis).
  • There is suprapapillary thinning of the epidermis above the dermal papillae.
  • Munro microabscesses and spongiform pustules may also be seen.

Explanation of Other Options:

Marked acanthosis (Option A): Seen in psoriasis due to increased keratinocyte proliferation.

Regular downward elongation of rete ridges (Option B): Described as resembling test tubes in a rack, characteristic of psoriasis.

Suprapapillary thinning of epidermis (Option D): Seen over the dermal papillae in psoriasis lesions.

questions.text: Darier's sign is typically seen in
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Darier's sign is a clinical feature of mastocytosis, particularly urticaria pigmentosa. Rubbing the lesion leads to erythema, swelling, and itching due to mast cell degranulation.

  • Seen in urticaria pigmentosa (a form of cutaneous mastocytosis)
  • Due to localised oedema from histamine release when the lesion is stroked
  • The histological exam shows dermal mast cell infiltration
  • The diagnosis can be confirmed by mast cell markers like tryptase or KIT

Explanation of Other Options:

Darier disease (Option A): Autosomal dominant keratinisation disorder due to ATP2A2 mutation; presents with warty papules, not mast cell infiltration or Darier sign.

Bullous pemphigoid (Option C): Autoimmune subepidermal blistering disease with eosinophilic infiltrate; Darier sign is absent.

Psoriasis (Option D): Chronic inflammatory dermatosis with acanthosis, parakeratosis, and Munro microabscesses; no mast cell degranulation or Darier sign.
